conclusion: The ball of mass m is placed on a smooth vertical ring. The ball is connected to a light rope that passes through a smooth hole at the top of the ring. The rope makes an angle θ with the vertical direction. The ball is in static equilibrium, meaning the net force acting on it is zero.

The forces acting on the ball are: Gravitational force (mg) acting vertically downward, Tension in the rope (T) acting along the rope, making an angle θ with the vertical, and Normal force (N) acting perpendicular to the surface of the ring, pointing radially inward.

premise: The vertical component of the tension is T cosθ. The gravitational force is mg. Since the ball is in equilibrium, the vertical forces must balance.
The horizontal component of the tension is T sinθ. The normal force N acts radially inward. Since the ball is in equilibrium, the horizontal forces must balance.

The force F is the upward force applied at the top of the rope to maintain equilibrium. This force is equal to the tension T in the rope because the rope is light and smooth, and there is no other force acting along the rope. From T cosθ = mg, solve for T.
The force F applied at the top of the rope is equal to the tension T.
